title: 110_s2285
content: The Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007, also known as the TRIA, defines acts of terrorism, reauthorizes the program, sets an annual liability cap, and requires enhanced reports to Congress. The definition of an act of terrorism under the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to exclude actions on behalf of foreign entities. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Termination Date to 2014 and include Additional Program Years up to 2014. Conforming Amendments are made to the Act. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Termination Date to 2014 and include Additional Program Years up to 2014. Conforming Amendments are made to the Act, including adjustments for subsequent Program Years. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Termination Date to 2014 and include Additional Program Years up to 2014. Adjustments for subsequent Program Years are made, including an Annual Liability Cap. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to adjust provisions related to insured losses and insurer payments. Insurers are not required to pay more than their deductible combined with their share of insured losses. Amendments also include changes to notice requirements to Congress. The Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to require the Secretary to notify Congress within 15 days of an act of terrorism if insured losses are estimated to exceed $100 billion. Regulations for pro rata payments and reporting to Congress are also updated. The Secretary must issue final regulations within 240 days of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007 for determining pro rata share of insured losses over $100 billion. A report to Congress is required within 120 days of the enactment. The Secretary must issue final regulations within 240 days of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007 for determining pro rata share of insured losses over $100 billion. A report to Congress is required within 120 days of the enactment, detailing the process for allocating payments for insured losses under the Program. Additionally, insurers must disclose clear and specific information for policies issued after the Act's enactment. The insurer must provide clear disclosure of the $100 billion cap to policyholders at the time of policy offer, purchase, and renewal under the Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007. SEC. 5. ENHANCED REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Comptroller General of the United States will study the availability and affordability of insurance coverage for losses from terrorist attacks involving nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological materials, as well as the future outlook for such coverage and the capacity of insurers to manage associated risks. The Comptroller General will study insurance coverage for terrorist attacks involving nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological materials and submit a report with recommendations to expand availability and affordability of insurance for such events. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the availability and affordability of terrorism insurance in specific markets, analyzing insurance and reinsurance capacity, pricing, and coverage limits in existing policies. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on terrorism insurance availability and affordability, analyzing capacity, pricing, and coverage limits in existing policies. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House committees within 180 days. Ongoing analysis will be conducted as well. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House committees within 180 days. Ongoing analysis will be conducted as well. Amendments include inserting "ongoing" before "analysis" and making adjustments to paragraph (2) by adding years and changing references.
